commit_message:
Spec for limiting GET /allocation_candidates

This specification provides a model for limiting the number of
allocation candidates that are returned when making a request to ``GET
/allocation_candidates`` while maintaining reasonable performance and
not impacting pack versus spread behavior.

Change-Id: I214ec871cdf7914b0f358e172471c3dfc7400367
Blueprint: allocation-candidates-limit
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/40/504540/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================== Limiting Allocation Candidates ============================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/allocation-candidates-limit This specification provides a model for limiting the number of allocation candidates that are returned when making a request to ``GET /allocation_candidates`` while maintaining reasonable performance and not impacting pack versus spread behavior. Problem description =================== In a large and sparse cloud (e.g. 10,000 empty compute nodes), a request of ``GET /allocation_candidates?resource=VCPU:1`` can return information for 10,000 resource providers. This has implications for memory and performance on both the placement service and in the client (in the present day, the nova-scheduler). A simple solution to this problem would be to add a ``limit`` query parameter to the request to limit the number of results. There are significant problems with this: * Limiting the database results without an ``ORDER BY`` clause will mean that results are ordered by whatever the natural order of the database is and some resource providers will show up in the chosen results more often, leading over time to packed placements, which may not be desired. * Using an ``ORDER BY`` clause with an existing column (such as resource provider uuid) will also lead to packed placements, because the order will always put the same results near the front. * Using an ``ORDER BY`` with a calculated value (such as `RAND()` or doing a bitmask on the uuid) will not bias the results, but will require a table scan destroying the performance benefits provide by database table indexes. The ideal solution is one that has no impact on pack versus spread behavior but still uses indexes as much as possible. In discussion at the Denver PTG no straightforward ideal solution was found, but something pretty close was, described below. Use Cases --------- As a client of the placement service I would like to optionally be able to request a limited number of allocation candidates in a performant fashion. Proposed change =============== The proposed solution to this problem has three parts: * In a new microversion accept an optional ``limit`` query parameter on the ``GET /allocation_candidates`` whose value expresses the maximum number of allocation candidates that will be returned in the response. At this time no support for expressing pagination or ordering is being considered. The value means the first N candidates. If unset, there is no limit. * Add a `limiter` column to the `resource_providers` table the value of which will be used to order the limited results. This will initially be populated with a random integer in a large range. Adjust the queries used to get the resource providers involved in allocation candidates to to limit by the limit and order by that column. When a resource provider is created, set the column. If the system prefers to bias for pack, we are done. * For systems that prefer a bias for spread, add a periodic job which updates the random numbers in the added column. The choice to do so will be controlled by a configuration option, ``randomize_candidates``. When true the periodic job will run. This update must take care to not update the ``updated_at`` column in the table. At this time, the placement service has no capacity to run a periodic job. It solely handles web requests. In a WSGI application one common and relatively simple way to do this is to run a task in the thread or process handling a request and response, after the response has been sent to the client:: try: start_response('200 OK', []) return ['my', 'stuff'] finally: if time_p(): periodic_job() This can only work if the WSGI application returns content as a list of strings. The placement service follows this pattern, and as a JSON API will continue to do so. The conditional functional (``time_p``) that decides if ``periodic_job`` should run will probably check to see if a fixed amount of time has passed since the current process updated the random column. In a distributed environment this could lead to multiple processes attempting to update the column at the same time. Alternatives ------------ * We could add limit to ``GET /resource_providers`` too. * We could set a relatively low default value for limit. * We can choose to not limit the size of the response. This is protection for a worst case scenario for which there exist other workarounds such as making flavors and other boot request impacting structures have sufficient detail to always limit the size of the response. We can also say that 10,000 results really isn't that big of a deal. * We can sort by an existing field (such as resource provider uuid) when doing a limit, effectively setting placement bias to pack. * We can use an integer value for ``randomize_candidates``, the value of which is the amount of time, in seconds, that should pass before another update. If 0, no update is done. This could be used to limit the overlapping updates described above if people were feeling enthusiastic with their configuration management. * We can use the new base service, etcd, to provide a distributed lock to avoid overlapping updates and store the last updated time. Or any of many other locking strategies. * Instead of relying on a quirk WSGI response handling, we can introduce threading or processing spawning into the placement service to handle the update job. This is not a great idea as it is a risk in the face of the different levels of support that WSGI servers have for threading and signal handling. * We can document that people who want spread handling should run a cron job to update the column. * We could adjust the update task so it can be run either once (ever), once per process, or on the interval described by configuration. For a first pass, the relatively simple model proposed above will work and can be incrementally improved or adjusted if there are issues. Data model impact ----------------- A database migration to add the ``limiter`` column to the ``resource_providers`` table in the API database is required. This new column should be set when creating a new resource provider, but otherwise is untouched until the first (and potentially only) update task runs. The column's type is Integer and it should be indexed. REST API impact --------------- Extend the query parameter schema for the ``GET /allocation_candidates`` request to, in a new microversion, accept a ``limit`` parameter that takes an integer value representing the maximum number of candidates that will be returned. Security impact --------------- N/A Notifications impact -------------------- N/A Other end user impact --------------------- N/A Performance Impact ------------------ The purpose of this change is to enhance performance by limiting the size of generated result sets. However in an environment where there are a very large number of resource providers the update job could generate a lot of work. Other deployer impact --------------------- N/A Developer impact ---------------- N/A Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: cdent Other contributors: rgerganov Work Items ---------- * Create a migration to add the ``limiter`` column. * Set that column to a random integer when creating a resource provider. * Add a facility to run a post-response task in the placement WSGI application (in nova/api/openstack/placement/handler.py). * Add a task for updating every row in the ``limiter`` column (but not the ``updated_at`` column). * Add a configuration setting as described above that controls how often that task is run. * Add ``limit`` to the ``GET /allocation_candidates`` query parameter JSON schema * Adjust `AllocationCandidates.get_by_filters` to accept an optional ``limit`` parameter, to be used in the generated SQL. * Update unit tests to check migration. * Update functional tests to confirm the full column update that happens in the post-response task and confirm the functionality of ``get_by_filters``. * Update gabbi tests for ``GET /allocation_candidates`` to exercise the ``limit`` functionality. Dependencies ============ N/A Testing ======= We should observe tempest and functional tests to confirm that new warnings and errors are not produced by the post-response task. Documentation Impact ==================== N/A References ========== N/A History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Queens - Introduced

commit_message:
3rd party integration document.

This is an attempt to document how to integrate a new container
or extend an existing one and include it in a TripleO deployment.

Change-Id: I10109341ad547645611337c582db1b63a349c5ae
Co-Authored-By: Dan Prince <dprince@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-docs refs/changes/36/505836/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Integrating 3rd Party Containers in TripleO =========================================== Building Containers ------------------- Adding layers to existing containers .................................... Any extra RPMs required by 3rd party drivers may need to be post-installed into our stock TripleO containers. In this case the 3rd party vendor may opt to add a layer to an existing container in order to deploy their software. The example below demonstrates how to extend a container on the Undercloud host machine. It assumes you are running a local docker registry on the undercloud. We recommend that you create a Dockerfile to extend the existing container. For example:: FROM 127.0.0.1:8787/tripleoupstream/centos-binary-cinder-volume MAINTAINER Vendor X LABEL name="tripleoupstream/centos-binary-cinder-volume-vendorx" vendor="Vendor X" version="2.1" release="1" # switch to root and install a custom RPM, etc. USER root COPY vendor_x.rpm /tmp RUN rpm -ivh /tmp/vendor_x.rpm # switch the container back to the default user USER cinder Docker build the container above using `docker build` on the command line. This will output a container image <ID> (used below to tag it). Create a docker tag and push it into the local registry:: docker tag <ID> 127.0.0.1:8787/tripleoupstream/centos-binary-cinder-volume-vendorx docker push 127.0.0.1:8787/tripleoupstream/centos-binary-cinder-volume-vendorx Create a Heat environment to configure a custom docker image override for Cinder:: parameter_defaults: DockerCinderVolumeImage: centos-binary-cinder-volume-vendorx:latest Start an overcloud deployment as normal with the extra custom Heat environment above to obtain the new container. .. warning:: Note that the new container will have the complete software stack built into it as is normal for containers. When other containers are updated and include security fixes in these lower layers, this container will NOT be updated as a result and will require rebuilding. Building new containers with kolla-build ........................................ To create new containers, or modify existing ones, you can use ``kolla-build`` from the `Kolla`_ project to build and push the images yourself. The command to build a new containers is below. Note that this assumes you are on an undercloud host:: kolla-build --base centos --type binary --namespace master --registry 192.168.24.1:8787 --tag latest --template-override /usr/share/tripleo-common/container-images/tripleo_kolla_template_overrides.j2 --push Notice that TripleO already uses the ``/usr/share/tripleo-common/container-images/tripleo_kolla_template_overrides.j2`` to add or change specific aspects of the containers. This file can be copied and modified to create custom containers. The original copy of this file can be found in the `tripleo-common`_ repository. The following template is an example of the template used for building the base images that are consumed by TripleO. In this case we are adding the `puppet` RPM to the base image:: {% extends parent_template %} {% set base_centos_binary_packages_append = ['puppet'] %} {% set nova_scheduler_packages_append = ['openstack-tripleo-common'] %} .. _Kolla: https://docs.openstack.org/developer/kolla/image-building.html#dockerfile-customisation .. _tripleo-common: https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-common/blob/master/container-images/tripleo_kolla_template_overrides.j2 Integrating 3rd party containers with tripleo-heat-templates ------------------------------------------------------------ The `TripleO Heat Templates`_ repo is where most of the logic resides in the form of heat templates. These templates define each service, the containers' configuration and the initialization or post-execution operations. .. _TripleO Heat Templates: http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates The docker templates can be found under the `docker` sub directory in the `tripleo-heat-templates` root. The services files are under the `docker/service` directory. For more information on how to integrate containres into the TripleO Heat templates, see the ``install/containers_deployment/architecture.rst`` document. (FIXME: proper link)

commit_message:
monasca-agent: add python-toml require

The monasca-setup InfluxDB detection plugin uses python-toml which may
not be available on the machine running InfluxDB (it's not required
by InfluxDB itself). Hence this commit adds it as a Require to ensure
it's always present.

Change-Id: I55939a7a7e46bb74269af055584b9f02f2658876

Add missing subnets key to DeloyedServerPortMap

This corrects the second example showing usage of DeployedServerPortMap,
where the subnets key was accidentally omitted.

commit_message:
heat-engine as Deployment or StatefulSet

heat-engine service can be now configured to be either Deployment or
StatefulSet.

Additionally this commit removes /var/cache/heat volume, as it's not
used by heat-engine or other heat services at all.

Change-Id: I541a1efc7817beb5f05d4cce216d9ea1cf378d7a
Co-Authored-By: Mateusz Blaszkowski <mateusz.blaszkowski@intel.com>

commit_message:
Add use-local-scheduler spec

Look at simplifying the number of services deployers need to worry about
when deploying Nova.

blueprint use-conductor-scheduler

Change-Id: I6ced22cb066a2093711d3814a07513e595f11843
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/36/438936/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================== Use Local Scheduler =================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/use-local-scheduler Nova has a lot of separate workers, particular when considering a full cells deployment, even with cells v2 there are multiple nova-compute process. This spec looks at simplifying the deployment for the majority of deploymnets. Problem description =================== Make Nova easier to deploy by reducing the number of services you need to run. This is more about the problems we no longer solve by separating conductor and scheduler. Previously we needed to independently scale nova-conductor and nova-scheduler, but now placement API is doing most of the DB work the scheduler previously had to do. Also the benefit from running a single scheduler process is much less because of the parallelism you get inside placement API. Use Cases --------- Here are the following deployments to consider: * Single cell cells v2 setup, small number of compute nodes * Multiple cell cells v2 setup, many compute nodes * Legacy cells v1 setup, running caching scheduler driver Proposed change =============== For a legacy cells v1 setup, we keep the same number of processes they have today. Running the caching scheduler, you want a single scheduler process per cell. For the moment that also bypasses the placement API. When we drop cells v1, we can drop this setup, so we should now deprecate this setup. By default we can have use_local_scheduler=True, which means: * create a scheduler api that either calls the manager code directly when use_local is True, and make an RPC call when False. * log a warning if use_local_scheduler is set to False * this means the scheduler code now runs inline inside nova-conductor, where all calls to the scheduler are made (TODO - is that true?) Other services -------------- In addition, we should also remove nova-cert and nova-console-auth. They are to ensure the load is removed from the API, but we can do that in the conductor now. The cert API is deprecated, we can add make it rpc call conductor, rather than the nova-cert API when cert_use_conductor=True In a similar way, when console_auth_use_conductor = True will call the conductor to run the usual code, rather than calling console_auth Alternatives ------------ We could do nothing. We could make conductor listen on the scheduler, cert and console_auth queues, but really we are looking to reduce the complexity, so less queues to worry about should deployers in the longer term. It does remove our ability to select which jobs a conductor does, but we should add that back in a better way if it turns out we need that. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- Notification still appear to come from the scheduler as before, until we remove the scheduler all together. Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ You may now need additional API cell nova-conductor processes to take the load that was previously on the scheduler process. Other deployer impact --------------------- Less services that need to be monitored and have HA explored, in particular we remove the need to run and manage: * nova-scheduler * nova-cert * nova-console-auth This leaves us with: * wsgi workers for api, metadata-api, and placement * eventlet workers for nova-conductor and nova-compute * other workers for novnc-proxy, serial-proxy, spice-proxy, xvp-proxy Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: John Garbutt (johnthetubaguy) Other contributors: OSIC Work Items ---------- * add use_local_scheduler with default of False * add other service transitions * get the gate testing the new configuration, i.e. use_local_scheduler = True * once testing is stable, switch the default of use_local_scheduler to True, etc. * deprecate all the config options we have added, to be removed with nova-cells Dependencies ============ This work assumes we have completed moving all the APIs to be hosted by a regular wsgi handler such as uwsgi or mod_wsgi. But it does not depend on that effort in any way. Testing ======= We should move gate jobs to use_local_scheduler = True, and no longer run the scheduler process. Same for all other processes. We should keep the cells v1 job still testing the legacy setup. Documentation Impact ==================== Update admin guide to reflect these changes. References ========== None History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Pike - Introduced

commit_message:
Fix ConfigDebug for puppet host runs

Before pike we used to be able to add -e environments/config-debug.yaml
and that would give us debug logs for puppet. With the move to ansible
running puppet we lost this feature.

Let's make sure that the old ConfigDebug variable still works with
the ansible playbook-based deploy steps. With this patch and ConfigDebug
set to true, we correctly get the puppet debug logs:

TASK [debug] *******************************************************************
ok: [localhost] => {
    "(outputs.stderr|default('')).split('\n')|union(outputs.stdout_lines|default([]))": [
        "Warning: Undefined variable 'deploy_config_name'; ",
        "   (file & line not available)",
        "Warning: This method is deprecated, please use the stdlib validate_legacy function, with Stdlib::Compat::Bool. There is further documentation for validate_legacy function in the README. at [\"/etc/puppet/modules/ntp/manifests/init.pp\", 54]:[\"/etc/puppet/modules/tripleo/manifests/profile/base/time/ntp.pp\", 29]",
        "   (at /etc/puppet/modules/stdlib/lib/puppet/functions/deprecation.rb:25:in `deprecation')",
        "Debug: Runtime environment: puppet_version=4.8.2, ruby_version=2.0.0, run_mode=user, default_encoding=UTF-8",
        "Debug: Loading external facts from /etc/puppet/modules/openstacklib/facts.d",
        "Debug: Loading external facts from /var/lib/puppet/facts.d",
....

Change-Id: Ia726fb8ca4a6f7bbbd7a1284d76ff42df6825d01
Closes-Bug: #1722752
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/07/511207/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: Set host puppet debugging fact string set_fact: host_puppet_config_debug: "--debug --verbose" when: enable_debug puppet apply "{{ host_puppet_config_debug|default('') }}"

subject: Include all rootwrap filters when building wheels
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-09-21 14:04:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/designate/commit/6a7c1a92162ceedce5964fe3db6cb77ed976bf35', 'message': 'Include all rootwrap filters when building wheels

The current method of specifying each rootwrap filter
in the file list is prone to errors when adding or
removing filters. Instead of relying on a manually
maintained list this patch just includes all the files
of the correct naming convention from the applicable
folder. This is simpler and easier to maintain.

Change-Id: I116efd3ff1799965bb46da785b2ad96c7f5b97c5
Closes-Bug: #1718356
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-09-22 11:37:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/designate/commit/e756c0c3965a9adfeeb4e3fcc970bd1431180cbb', 'message': 'Include all rootwrap filters when building wheels

in the file list is prone to errors when adding or
removing filters. Instead of relying on a manually
maintained list this patch just includes all the files
of the correct naming convention from the applicable
folder. This is simpler and easier to maintain.

Closes-Bug: #1718356

maintained list this patch just includes all the files
of the correct naming convention from the applicable

commit_message:
Include all rootwrap filters when building wheels

The current method of specifying each rootwrap filter
in the file list is prone to errors when adding or
removing filters. Instead of relying on a manually
maintained list this patch just includes all the files
of the correct naming convention from the applicable
folder. This is simpler and easier to maintain.

Change-Id: I116efd3ff1799965bb46da785b2ad96c7f5b97c5
Closes-Bug: #1718356

commit_message:
Documentation and release notes for plugins

In Icde2b26a38d7c7842defae053228d9208454b969, we added support for
stevedore based external/custom plugins. In this changeset, we
add a release note and documentation on how things work.

Change-Id: Ie0b773dc1147f5ef898d17e8f84c946c39fdf5cd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.policy refs/changes/16/510616/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- features: - | Add support for custom rule check plugins. ``http`` and ``https`` external rule checks have been converted into stevedore plugins and serve as examples.

commit_message:
Introduce a SR-IOV binding driver

The driver is for binding/unbinding SR-IOV port. Basically,
what it does is setting the vlan id for the VF interface.

Change-Id: Ife43b57a11c9aac9c0bece84adf719e62f708fda
Partial-Implements: blueprint sriov-binding

commit_message:
Updated from global requirements

Change-Id: I4520591eefecd30a084a0f84b91130e855913e5f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kuryr refs/changes/48/496048/74 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: pyroute2>=0.4.19 # Apache-2.0 (+ dual licensed GPL2)

subject: Support traits in the Ironic driver
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-09-25 10:32:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/3e93fba93d23f5915008d76524cb25b1505e4711', 'message': 'WIP: Support traits in the Ironic driver

Placeholder spec for the traits support being added to the Ironic
driver. The depends on changes in Ironic to allow operators to set
traits on ironic nodes, alongside the existing ability to add a resource
class for each node.

Depends-On: Ia181b1bb3188042dc0d17e02c5f7628194c34dad

blueprint ironic-driver-traits

Change-Id: Ice5468aaefc2f6d0ae8f6b0e86f2096f45b75919
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-09-27 18:05:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/14b349fa93a02fa20635ce028138172a93985b54', 'message': 'Support traits in the Ironic driver

TODO: several open questions around who sets traits on a given resource
provider.

We need scheduling that is more granular than resource classes. Traits
are the best way to do that. This talks about how we integrate ironic
nodes having associated traits into a Nova boot.

The depends on changes in Ironic to allow operators to set
traits on ironic nodes, alongside the existing ability to add a resource
class for each node.

Depends-On: Ia181b1bb3188042dc0d17e02c5f7628194c34dad

blueprint ironic-driver-traits

Change-Id: Ice5468aaefc2f6d0ae8f6b0e86f2096f45b75919
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2017-09-29 10:35:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/c477a9aaea6301b78486c4a9c546ae88f490dedf', 'message': 'Support traits in the Ironic driver

TODO: several open questions around who sets traits on a given resource
provider.

We need scheduling that is more granular than resource classes. Traits
are the best way to do that. This talks about how we integrate ironic
nodes having associated traits into a Nova boot.

The depends on changes in Ironic to allow operators to set
traits on ironic nodes, alongside the existing ability to add a resource
class for each node.

Depends-On: Ia181b1bb3188042dc0d17e02c5f7628194c34dad

blueprint ironic-driver-traits

Change-Id: Ice5468aaefc2f6d0ae8f6b0e86f2096f45b75919
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2017-10-03 16:12:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/585463f33a25eac94d6a70ffdfd0b5b98016c514', 'message': 'Support traits in the Ironic driver

commit_message:
Support traits in the Ironic driver

We need scheduling that is more granular than resource classes. Traits
are the best way to do that. This talks about how we integrate ironic
nodes having associated traits into a Nova boot.

This spec depends on changes in Ironic to allow operators to set
traits on ironic nodes, alongside the existing ability to add a resource
class for each node.

blueprint ironic-driver-traits

Change-Id: Ice5468aaefc2f6d0ae8f6b0e86f2096f45b75919
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/52/507052/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================== Support traits in the Ironic driver =================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/ironic-driver-traits To allow more granular scheduling of Ironic resources, Ironic is exposing traits for each ironic node, which in turn must be reported up to placement via the ironic driver. Problem description =================== TODO... Use Cases --------- What use cases does this address? What impact on actors does this change have? Ensure you are clear about the actors in each use case: Developer, End User, Deployer etc. Proposed change =============== Here is where you cover the change you propose to make in detail. How do you propose to solve this problem? If this is one part of a larger effort make it clear where this piece ends. In other words, what's the scope of this effort? At this point, if you would like to just get feedback on if the problem and proposed change fit in nova, you can stop here and post this for review to get preliminary feedback. If so please say: Posting to get preliminary feedback on the scope of this spec. Alternatives ------------ What other ways could we do this thing? Why aren't we using those? This doesn't have to be a full literature review, but it should demonstrate that thought has been put into why the proposed solution is an appropriate one. Data model impact ----------------- Changes which require modifications to the data model often have a wider impact on the system. The community often has strong opinions on how the data model should be evolved, from both a functional and performance perspective. It is therefore important to capture and gain agreement as early as possible on any proposed changes to the data model. Questions which need to be addressed by this section include: * What new data objects and/or database schema changes is this going to require? * What database migrations will accompany this change. * How will the initial set of new data objects be generated, for example if you need to take into account existing instances, or modify other existing data describe how that will work. REST API impact --------------- Each API method which is either added or changed should have the following * Specification for the method * A description of what the method does suitable for use in user documentation * Method type (POST/PUT/GET/DELETE) * Normal http response code(s) * Expected error http response code(s) * A description for each possible error code should be included describing semantic errors which can cause it such as inconsistent parameters supplied to the method, or when an instance is not in an appropriate state for the request to succeed. Errors caused by syntactic problems covered by the JSON schema definition do not need to be included. * URL for the resource * URL should not include underscores, and use hyphens instead. * Parameters which can be passed via the url * JSON schema definition for the request body data if allowed * Field names should use snake_case style, not CamelCase or MixedCase style. * JSON schema definition for the response body data if any * Field names should use snake_case style, not CamelCase or MixedCase style. * Example use case including typical API samples for both data supplied by the caller and the response * Discuss any policy changes, and discuss what things a deployer needs to think about when defining their policy. Example JSON schema definitions can be found in the Nova tree http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/tree/nova/api/openstack/compute/schemas Note that the schema should be defined as restrictively as possible. Parameters which are required should be marked as such and only under exceptional circumstances should additional parameters which are not defined in the schema be permitted (eg additionaProperties should be False). Reuse of existing predefined parameter types such as regexps for passwords and user defined names is highly encouraged. Security impact --------------- Describe any potential security impact on the system. Some of the items to consider include: * Does this change touch sensitive data such as tokens, keys, or user data? * Does this change alter the API in a way that may impact security, such as a new way to access sensitive information or a new way to login? * Does this change involve cryptography or hashing? * Does this change require the use of sudo or any elevated privileges? * Does this change involve using or parsing user-provided data? This could be directly at the API level or indirectly such as changes to a cache layer. * Can this change enable a resource exhaustion attack, such as allowing a single API interaction to consume significant server resources? Some examples of this include launching subprocesses for each connection, or entity expansion attacks in XML. For more detailed guidance, please see the OpenStack Security Guidelines as a reference (https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Security/Guidelines). These guidelines are a work in progress and are designed to help you identify security best practices. For further information, feel free to reach out to the OpenStack Security Group at openstack-security@lists.openstack.org. Notifications impact -------------------- Please specify any changes to notifications. Be that an extra notification, changes to an existing notification, or removing a notification. Other end user impact --------------------- Aside from the API, are there other ways a user will interact with this feature? * Does this change have an impact on python-novaclient? What does the user interface there look like? Performance Impact ------------------ Describe any potential performance impact on the system, for example how often will new code be called, and is there a major change to the calling pattern of existing code. Examples of things to consider here include: * A periodic task might look like a small addition but if it calls conductor or another service the load is multiplied by the number of nodes in the system. * Scheduler filters get called once per host for every instance being created, so any latency they introduce is linear with the size of the system. * A small change in a utility function or a commonly used decorator can have a large impacts on performance. * Calls which result in a database queries (whether direct or via conductor) can have a profound impact on performance when called in critical sections of the code. * Will the change include any locking, and if so what considerations are there on holding the lock? Other deployer impact --------------------- Discuss things that will affect how you deploy and configure OpenStack that have not already been mentioned, such as: * What config options are being added? Should they be more generic than proposed (for example a flag that other hypervisor drivers might want to implement as well)? Are the default values ones which will work well in real deployments? * Is this a change that takes immediate effect after its merged, or is it something that has to be explicitly enabled? * If this change is a new binary, how would it be deployed? * Please state anything that those doing continuous deployment, or those upgrading from the previous release, need to be aware of. Also describe any plans to deprecate configuration values or features. For example, if we change the directory name that instances are stored in, how do we handle instance directories created before the change landed? Do we move them? Do we have a special case in the code? Do we assume that the operator will recreate all the instances in their cloud? Developer impact ---------------- Discuss things that will affect other developers working on OpenStack, such as: * If the blueprint proposes a change to the driver API, discussion of how other hypervisors would implement the feature is required. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Who is leading the writing of the code? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? If more than one person is working on the implementation, please designate the primary author and contact. Primary assignee: <launchpad-id or None> Other contributors: <launchpad-id or None> Work Items ---------- Work items or tasks -- break the feature up into the things that need to be done to implement it. Those parts might end up being done by different people, but we're mostly trying to understand the timeline for implementation. Dependencies ============ * Include specific references to specs and/or blueprints in nova, or in other projects, that this one either depends on or is related to. * If this requires functionality of another project that is not currently used by Nova (such as the glance v2 API when we previously only required v1), document that fact. * Does this feature require any new library dependencies or code otherwise not included in OpenStack? Or does it depend on a specific version of library? Testing ======= Please discuss the important scenarios needed to test here, as well as specific edge cases we should be ensuring work correctly. For each scenario please specify if this requires specialized hardware, a full openstack environment, or can be simulated inside the Nova tree. Please discuss how the change will be tested. We especially want to know what tempest tests will be added. It is assumed that unit test coverage will be added so that doesn't need to be mentioned explicitly, but discussion of why you think unit tests are sufficient and we don't need to add more tempest tests would need to be included. Is this untestable in gate given current limitations (specific hardware / software configurations available)? If so, are there mitigation plans (3rd party testing, gate enhancements, etc). Documentation Impact ==================== Which audiences are affected most by this change, and which documentation titles on docs.openstack.org should be updated because of this change? Don't repeat details discussed above, but reference them here in the context of documentation for multiple audiences. For example, the Operations Guide targets cloud operators, and the End User Guide would need to be updated if the change offers a new feature available through the CLI or dashboard. If a config option changes or is deprecated, note here that the documentation needs to be updated to reflect this specification's change. References ========== Please add any useful references here. You are not required to have any reference. Moreover, this specification should still make sense when your references are unavailable. Examples of what you could include are: * Links to mailing list or IRC discussions * Links to notes from a summit session * Links to relevant research, if appropriate * Related specifications as appropriate (e.g. if it's an EC2 thing, link the EC2 docs) * Anything else you feel it is worthwhile to refer to History ======= Optional section intended to be used each time the spec is updated to describe new design, API or any database schema updated. Useful to let reader understand what's happened along the time. .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Queens - Introduced

commit_message:
pass $HOME to tox commands so git can find its config file

list-changes now needs to be able to add a temporary tag to build the
release notes. Adding the tag requires identity information not previously
required for other git commands, and git needs to know where HOME is to
find that info.

Change-Id: Ia9a506bdfa30cf72b48d53a7ec05b0bc939f34a6
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/releases refs/changes/97/512297/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: switch from Popen to check_output in release notes tools
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-10-16 13:23:12.000000000', 'files': ['openstack_releases/release_notes.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/releases/commit/3fc5805761bcf10684d624e726fa6cd1a9da18f5', 'message': "switch from Popen to check_output in release notes tools

The copy of release_notes.py imported from the release-tools repo was
modified to use Popen instead of oslo.concurrency. However, that
change was made incorrectly, and an invalid exception was being
caught. When the commands work fine, this doesn't present a
problem. When the commands fail, it breaks error handling. Replace all
of the local logic with check_call(), the function used elsewhere in
this repo for running background commands. Update users of run_cmd()
in release_notes.py to only expect to receive stdout as a response.

Change-Id: I291a077ed613c3e4ad56b85c81945c15a6301c17
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
"}]
commit_message:
switch from Popen to check_output in release notes tools

The copy of release_notes.py imported from the release-tools repo was
modified to use Popen instead of oslo.concurrency. However, that
change was made incorrectly, and an invalid exception was being
caught. When the commands work fine, this doesn't present a
problem. When the commands fail, it breaks error handling. Replace all
of the local logic with check_call(), the function used elsewhere in
this repo for running background commands. Update users of run_cmd()
in release_notes.py to only expect to receive stdout as a response.

Change-Id: I291a077ed613c3e4ad56b85c81945c15a6301c17
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/releases refs/changes/96/512296/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

dont use raise_for_status

use the webob abort method for http errors
(cherry picked from commit fa9aa52)

commit_message:
Validate extension for tarballs on plan create/update

Stop the user from uploading a plan file if it is not a tar archive.

Change-Id: I38400546f860adc33a3de33176c8a557d2180810
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ui refs/changes/45/508145/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

and pypi jobs. This patches blindly adds requirements like in [1].

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-09-20 21:42:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/58c087bd2abf72beb0707db06a7a5fb4693954fc', 'message': 'Config download support for standalone deployments

Presently, "openstack overcloud config download" only supports the
OS::HeatSoftwareDeployments (plural) resources from deploy-steps.yaml.

This patch adds support for also pulling all the deployment data for
OS::Heat::SoftwareDeployment (singular) resources applied to individual
servers. Those resources are mapped to a new nested stack via the
config-download-environment.yaml environment.

The nested stack has the same interface as a SoftwareDeployment but only
creates a OS::Heat::Value resource. The "config download" code will be
updated in a separate patch to read the deployment data from these Value
resources and apply them via ansible.

Change-Id: Ic2af634403b1ab2924c383035f770453f39a2cd5

commit_message:
Config download support for standalone deployments

Presently, "openstack overcloud config download" does not support all
Deployment resources, only those included in the RoleData and are
natively of type group:ansible.

This patch adds support for also pulling all the deployment data for
OS::Heat::SoftwareDeployment (singular) resources applied to individual
servers of any group type. Those resources are mapped to a new nested
stack via the config-download-environment.yaml environment.

The nested stack has the same interface as a SoftwareDeployment but only
creates a OS::Heat::Value resource. The "config download" code will be
updated in a separate patch to read the deployment data from these Value
resources and apply them via ansible.

The related tripleo-common patch (which depends on this patch) is:
I7d7f6b831b8566390d8f747fb6f45e879b0392ba

implements: blueprint ansible-config-download
Change-Id: Ic2af634403b1ab2924c383035f770453f39a2cd5

commit_message:
Split get_allocations_for_instance() into useful bits

We now call this method for other types of consumers, like migrations,
so the name needs to change. Also, we need to be able to fetch allocations
without specifying a resource_provider. This splits and renames the method
so it can be used in this way.

Related to blueprint migration-allocations

Change-Id: I2d27ae23aace1b7f14b5556af1693169391d4b2c

deleted_lines: mig_allocs = self.reportclient.get_allocations_for_instance( cn_uuid, migration) allocs = self.reportclient.get_allocations_for_instance( cn_uuid, migration)

commit_message:
Add snap support

Enable snap installation support for Gnocchi.

The Gnocchi snap provides nginx and uwsgi instead of
Apache2 + mod_wsgi so the config/restart map looks a
little different.

Snap support has been implemented using a subclass of
the GnocchiCharmBase class, which provides common
methods and properties to both deb and snap based
installations.

Snaps are only published for Ocata or later releases
of OpenStack.

Change-Id: I464025a2b72aba8c31a4a97ade39d2b2980c3a92
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-gnocchi refs/changes/96/508896/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: user root root; worker_processes auto; pid /var/snap/gnocchi/common/run/nginx.pid; events { worker_connections 768; } http { ## # Basic Settings ## sendfile on; tcp_nopush on; tcp_nodelay on; keepalive_timeout 65; types_hash_max_size 2048; include /snap/gnocchi/current/usr/conf/mime.types; default_type application/octet-stream; ## # Logging Settings ## access_log /var/snap/gnocchi/common/log/nginx-access.log; error_log /var/snap/gnocchi/common/log/nginx-error.log; ## # Gzip Settings ## gzip on; gzip_disable "msie6"; include /var/snap/gnocchi/common/etc/nginx/conf.d/*.conf; include /var/snap/gnocchi/common/etc/nginx/sites-enabled/*; }

commit_message:
Sync deployed-server-roles-data and roles-data

deployed-server-roles-data was out of sync and missing some parameters
introduced in Pike cycle:
This patch syncs the roles_data between 2 files.

Change-Id: If4a8388634fb1dcbb47beeabbd3db005abc80d4e
Closes-Bug: #1723177

Remove windmill from zuul-legacy-project-templates

These have been moved into the windmill project.

commit_message:
Revert allocations by migration uuid

When we do a migration revert in the new style, the source
compute node is responsible for replacing the migration-owned
allocation on the compute node with an instance-owned one. This
replaces the allocation that the instance owned on the formerly-
destination node.

Related to blueprint migration-allocations

Change-Id: I7c3c95d4e0836e1af054d076aad29172574eab2c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/49/498949/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self._revert_allocation(instance, migration) def _revert_allocation(self, instance, migration): orig_alloc = self.reportclient.get_allocations_for_resource_provider( migration.uuid) if not orig_alloc: # NOTE(danms): This migration did not do per-migration allocation # accounting, so nothing to do here. return rt = self._get_resource_tracker() cn_uuid = rt.compute_nodes[instance.node].uuid # FIXME(danms): Since we don't have an atomic operation to adjust # allocations for multiple consumers, we have to have space on the # source for double the claim before we delete the old one resources = orig_alloc[cn_uuid]['resources'] # FIXME(danms): This method is flawed in that it asssumes allocations # against only one provider. So, this may overwite allocations against # a shared provider, if we had one. self.reportclient.put_allocations(cn_uuid, instance.uuid, resources, instance.project_id, instance.user_id) self.reportclient.delete_allocation_for_instance(migration.uuid)

subject: Just "import mock" as it works for Python 2 and 3
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-10-13 17:28:07.000000000', 'files': ['ironic_inspector/test/unit/test_swift.py', 'ironic_inspector/test/unit/test_utils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-inspector/commit/660b682764883ddb6bf85cbd5bba203f2f035edd', 'message': 'Just "import mock" as it works for Python 2 and 3

Don't try to special case "import mock" depending if Python 3 vs Python
2. It works to just use "import mock" no matter which version.

Change-Id: I35c67cb86559c0557a757c6a7664c3f56961dfe5
'}]
commit_message:
Just "import mock" as it works for Python 2 and 3

Don't try to special case "import mock" depending if Python 3 vs Python
2. It works to just use "import mock" no matter which version.

Change-Id: I35c67cb86559c0557a757c6a7664c3f56961dfe5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-inspector refs/changes/25/511925/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import mock
deleted_lines: try: from unittest import mock except ImportError: import mock

subject: Refactor resource tracker to account for migration allocations
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-09-22 00:26:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/db2ffaccd4103f65cae3d11256d676db0c68a0aa', 'message': "Refactor resource tracker to account for migration allocations

At the end of update_usage_from_instances(), we call the
_remove_deleted_instances_allocations() to clean up any allocations
that placement says are made against our resource provider. It assumes
that any such allocations that aren't in the known list of instances
must be deleted instances and it removes them. However, once we start
allowing migrations to own allocations against us, we need to make
sure we don't delete those prematurely.

This refactors the resource_tracker to call that method with the list
of migrations active for our node, and it avoids deleting allocations
for providers that match one of those known migrations.

Related to blueprint migration-allocations

Change-Id: Ib240cd863cfdbb538f46e7323b4e282fc3de56cb

commit_message:
Refactor resource tracker to account for migration allocations

At the end of update_usage_from_instances(), we call the
_remove_deleted_instances_allocations() to clean up any allocations
that placement says are made against our resource provider. It assumes
that any such allocations that aren't in the known list of instances
must be deleted instances and it removes them. However, once we start
allowing migrations to own allocations against us, we need to make
sure we don't delete those prematurely.

This refactors the resource_tracker to call that method with the list
of migrations active for our node, and it avoids deleting allocations
for providers that match one of those known migrations.

Related to blueprint migration-allocations

Change-Id: Ib240cd863cfdbb538f46e7323b4e282fc3de56cb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/19/506419/18 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self._remove_deleted_instances_allocations( context, self.compute_nodes[nodename], migrations) def _remove_deleted_instances_allocations(self, context, cn, migrations): migration_uuids = [migration.uuid for migration in migrations if 'uuid' in migration] for consumer_uuid, alloc in allocations.items(): if consumer_uuid in known_instances: consumer_uuid, alloc) if consumer_uuid in migration_uuids: LOG.debug("Migration %s is active on this compute host " "and has allocations in placement: %s.", consumer_uuid, alloc) continue # We know these are instances now, so proceed instance_uuid = consumer_uuid
deleted_lines: self._remove_deleted_instances_allocations(context, cn) def _remove_deleted_instances_allocations(self, context, cn): for instance_uuid, alloc in allocations.items(): if instance_uuid in known_instances: instance_uuid, alloc)

commit_message:
Fix syntax errors with set-service-type-data-fact role

Tasks key is not valid inside a role.

Change-Id: I5e6a98e483a13271d8b422162b4e3217e7b495fb
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-zuul-jobs refs/changes/67/512267/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: tasks: - name: Get service-types data file get_url: url: https://service-types.openstack.org/service-types.json dest: "{{ ansible_user_dir }}/service-types.json" - name: Collect service type data for project get_service_type_data: project_name: "{{ zuul.project.short_name }}" service_types_file: "{{ ansible_user_dir }}/service-types.json" register: service_type_data - name: Set service_type_data as a fact set_fact: service_type_data: service_type_data

Ocata's devstack still uses ami/aki/ari cirros image.
But incorrect code with 'bare' type was merged some time ago.
Need to change back 'bare' to 'ami'.

Change-Id: Ie1729f67f12e68117df742650b66b7bddef3d868

commit_message:
fix EBS image creation in Ocata

Ocata's devstack still uses ami/aki/ari cirros image.
But incorrect code with 'bare' type was merged some time ago.
Need to change back 'bare' to 'ami'.

Change-Id: Ie1729f67f12e68117df742650b66b7bddef3d868
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ec2-api refs/changes/41/511741/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: openstack_image_id=$(openstack $auth image list --long | grep "cirros" | grep " ami " | head -1 | awk '{print $2}')
deleted_lines: openstack_image_id=$(openstack $auth image list --long | grep "cirros" | grep " bare " | head -1 | awk '{print $2}')

commit_message:
Refactor init_instance:resume_guests_state

In the init instance, the resume_guests_state part
was too complex with our related patch and
necessary refactor this to any new method.
The related patch attached in comment

commit_message:
functests: don't crash if no second account

In test.functional.test_object.TestObject.setUp, we create a container
in account 2. However, if we've only got one account, we don't skip
this class, resulting in a TypeError down in requests somewhere and a
stack trace. Since we're using account 2 in setup, we should skip the
tests if account 2 is not configured.

Change-Id: I569d98baf071d2dce7cf34a9538070f00afda388

commit_message:
Setup networking for live migration tests

It turns out the live migration tests have always
been creating an instance with no networking, so
we haven't been testing any of the network setup
and port binding update logic that happens during
a live migration, which is bad.

This sets up networking so the instance will get
a port when it's created and then the port binding
should get updated once the live migration is complete.

Change-Id: I41cfae9a7912aa8e2f0010a7ec2fdbd45ebf5e9d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/83/511283/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def setup_credentials(cls): # These tests don't attempt any SSH validation nor do they use # floating IPs on the instance, so all we need is a network and # a subnet so the instance being migrated has a single port, but # we need that to make sure we are properly updating the port # host bindings during the live migration. # TODO(mriedem): SSH validation before and after the instance is # live migrated would be a nice test wrinkle addition. cls.set_network_resources(network=True, subnet=True) super(LiveMigrationTest, cls).setup_credentials() @classmethod

commit_message:
Skip cross-account-copy functest if only one account

This looks like a case of copy-paste-itis. The cross-account-copy
functest is skipped if we have no test accounts configured, but not if
we have only one.

Change-Id: Ifbefdd9aeb98e3d02c536e9d29759f86ec9af6a1

commit_message:
bagpipe: E-VPN route withdraw issue

The MPLS label or VXLAN id is encoded differently in the
ExaBGP wrapper for MAC routes than it is in IPVPN routes.

Change-Id: I8289fd016252f0cea3ea51466b06ff562fce1bf1
Closes-Bug: 1723911

subject: Filter out stale migrations in resource audit
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-08 16:59:39.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/c0b56a46273652cbc1daf4a12b3a52024f0b79b6', 'message': "Filter out stale migrations in resource audit

When doing the resource audit there is a subtle bug in the current
code.  The problem arises if:

1) You have one or more stale migrations which didn't complete
properly that involve the current compute node.

2) The instance from the uncompleted migration is currently doing a
resize/migration that does not involve the current compute node.

When this happens, _update_usage_from_migrations() will be passed in
the stale migration, and the instance is in fact in a resize state,
so the current compute node will erroneously account for the instance.

The fix is to check that the instance migration ID matches the ID
of the migration being analyzed.  This will work because in the case
of the stale migration we will have hit the error case in
_pair_instances_to_migrations(), and so the instance will be
lazy-loaded from the DB, ensuring that its migration ID is up-to-date.

Change-Id: I6f5ad01cb1392db3e2b71e322c5be353de9071a2

When doing the resource audit there is a subtle bug in the current
code.  The problem arises if:

1) You have one or more stale migrations which didn't complete
properly that involve the current compute node.

2) The instance from the uncompleted migration is currently doing a
resize/migration that does not involve the current compute node.

When this happens, _update_usage_from_migrations() will be passed in

of the migration being analyzed.  This will work because in the case
of the stale migration we will have hit the error case in

lazy-loaded from the DB, ensuring that its migration ID is up-to-date.

Closes-Bug: #1600304
Change-Id: I6f5ad01cb1392db3e2b71e322c5be353de9071a2

commit_message:
Filter out stale migrations in resource audit

When doing the resource audit there is a subtle bug in the current
code.  The problem arises if:

1) You have one or more stale migrations which didn't complete
properly that involve the current compute node.

2) The instance from the uncompleted migration is currently doing a
resize/migration that does not involve the current compute node.

When this happens, _update_usage_from_migrations() will be passed in
the stale migration, and the instance is in fact in a resize state,
so the current compute node will erroneously account for the instance.

The fix is to check that the instance migration ID matches the ID
of the migration being analyzed.  This will work because in the case
of the stale migration we will have hit the error case in
_pair_instances_to_migrations(), and so the instance will be
lazy-loaded from the DB, ensuring that its migration ID is up-to-date.

If the IDs don't match, we'll set the migration status to "error" (to
prevent retrieving that migration the next time) and skip updating
the usage from the stale migration.

Closes-Bug: #1600304
Change-Id: I6f5ad01cb1392db3e2b71e322c5be353de9071a2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/15/339715/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Skip migration if it doesn't match the instance migration id. # This can happen if we have a stale migration record. if (instance.migration_context is not None and instance.migration_context.migration_id != migration.id): LOG.warning(_LW("Instance migration %(im)s doesn't match " "migration %(m)s, skipping migration."), {'im': instance.migration_context.migration_id, 'm': migration.id}) continue

subject: nova-manage map_instances is not using the cells info from the API database
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-10-10 11:35:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/88df0f83c90987cb93701dd514e122875a46232c', 'message': 'nova-manage map_instances is not using the cells info from the API database

In order to map instances, nova-manage takes the database info of the cell from
the config file (so by default this points to cell0 in nova.conf) and so for
every new cell created, in order to do the map_instances, the correct --config-file
has to be specified in addition to the --cell_uuid option that is provided.

So it is better if this info is taken from the cell_mappings table inside the
nova-api database using the provided --cell_uuid.

Change-Id: Ib86e25bf8c4cd4008eae43c49c74f24b1b63518a
Closes-Bug: #1720130

commit_message:
nova-manage map_instances is not using the cells info from the API database

In order to map instances, nova-manage takes the database info of the cell from
the config file (so by default this points to cell0 in nova.conf) and so for
every new cell created, in order to do the map_instances, the correct --config-file
has to be specified in addition to the --cell_uuid option that is provided.

So it is better if this info is taken from the cell_mappings table inside the
nova-api database using the provided --cell_uuid.

Change-Id: Ib86e25bf8c4cd4008eae43c49c74f24b1b63518a
Closes-Bug: #1720130
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/44/510844/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: with context.target_cell(ctxt, cell_mapping) as cctxt: instances = objects.InstanceList.get_by_filters( cctxt.elevated(read_deleted='yes'), filters, sort_key='created_at', sort_dir='asc', limit=limit, marker=marker) Instances in the nova database of the provided cell (nova database info is obtained from the nova-api database) will be queried from oldest to newest and if unmapped, will be mapped to the provided cell.
deleted_lines: instances = objects.InstanceList.get_by_filters( ctxt.elevated(read_deleted='yes'), filters, sort_key='created_at', sort_dir='asc', limit=limit, marker=marker) This assumes that Nova on this host is still configured to use the nova database not just the nova-api database. Instances in the nova database will be queried from oldest to newest and mapped to the provided cell.

commit_message:
Remove system_metadata loading in Instance._load_flavor

We migrated the embedded instance flavor from system_metadata
to instance_extra back in Kilo, and you couldn't upgrade to
Liberty without doing that, so we no longer need this data
migration code to include system_metadata.

Also cleans up a few other related remnants from the migration.

Change-Id: I015755937fcbf4456ee502970e5d282ead570015

subject: TrivialFix: Fix the incorrect test case
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-10-05 12:09:32.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/test_api_validation.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/45682eb099f239b7bd1e8f6e19f6f022470d64c3', 'message': 'TrivialFix: Fix the incorrect test case

The below test case is not checking all validator schema formats
defined in list "checks":

nova.tests.unit.test_api_validation.FormatCheckerTestCase.
test_format_checker_failed_with_non_string

The loop variable "check" is never used in the for loop block instead
the same format "name" is tested for four times.

This patch seperates the test cases for each validator schema format
as the exception message is differemt for each one.

NOTE: Not used DDT to combine tests as with DDT it will be difficult to
figure out which validator format has failed.

Change-Id: Ic87128a5362d64534b50e8d1450bd3eca832afbd
'}]
commit_message:
TrivialFix: Fix the incorrect test case

The below test case is not checking all validator schema formats
defined in list "checks":

nova.tests.unit.test_api_validation.FormatCheckerTestCase.
test_format_checker_failed_with_non_string

The loop variable "check" is never used in the for loop block instead
the same format "name" is tested for four times.

This patch seperates the test cases for each validator schema format
as the exception message is differemt for each one.

NOTE: Not used DDT to combine tests as with DDT it will be difficult to
figure out which validator format has failed.

Change-Id: Ic87128a5362d64534b50e8d1450bd3eca832afbd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/58/509758/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _format_checker(self, format, value, error_message): format_checker.check, value, format) self.assertEqual(error_message, def test_format_checker_failed_with_non_string_name(self): error_message = ("An invalid 'name' value was provided. The name must " "be: printable characters. " "Can not start or end with whitespace.") self._format_checker("name", " ", error_message) self._format_checker("name", None, error_message) def test_format_checker_failed_with_non_string_cell_name(self): error_message = ("An invalid 'name' value was provided. " "The name must be: printable characters except " "!, ., @. Can not start or end with whitespace.") self._format_checker("cell_name", None, error_message) def test_format_checker_failed_name_with_leading_trailing_spaces(self): error_message = ("An invalid 'name' value was provided. " "The name must be: printable characters with at " "least one non space character") self._format_checker("name_with_leading_trailing_spaces", None, error_message) def test_format_checker_failed_cell_name_with_leading_trailing_spaces( self): error_message = ("An invalid 'name' value was provided. " "The name must be: printable characters except" " !, ., @, with at least one non space character") self._format_checker("cell_name_with_leading_trailing_spaces", None, error_message)
deleted_lines: def test_format_checker_failed(self): format_checker.check, " ", "name") self.assertEqual("An invalid 'name' value was provided. The name must " "be: printable characters. " "Can not start or end with whitespace.", def test_format_checker_failed_with_non_string(self): checks = ["name", "name_with_leading_trailing_spaces", "cell_name", "cell_name_with_leading_trailing_spaces"] format_checker = validators.FormatChecker() for check in checks: exc = self.assertRaises(jsonschema_exc.FormatError, format_checker.check, None, "name") self.assertIsInstance(exc.cause, exception.InvalidName) self.assertEqual("An invalid 'name' value was provided. The name " "must be: printable characters. " "Can not start or end with whitespace.", exc.cause.format_message())

commit_message:
Update services in the process count validation

This patch updates the services used in the process count validation.

No longer used:
  - glance-registry
  - ironic-api
New:
  - ironic-inspector

Change-Id: I7f37af45211183ad780974a2e14b0c76d46e3164
(cherry picked from commit aa33f07b062431d78b4674a71727ea3189cee145)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-validations refs/changes/20/511220/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - ironic-inspector

commit_message:
Replace the Gnocchi dispatcher by a publisher

This removes the deprecated Gnocchi dispatcher and replaces it by its
equivalent publisher.

Change-Id: Ie44baf20ccb8de5794f5f0c3d4717f7e56afa63b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/86/500586/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import six.moves.urllib.parse as urlparsefrom ceilometer import publisherclass GnocchiPublisher(publisher.ConfigPublisherBase): """Publisher class for recording metering data into the Gnocchi service. The publisher class records each meter into the gnocchi service configured in Ceilometer pipeline file. An example target may gnocchi://?archive_policy=low&filter_project=gnocchi def __init__(self, conf, parsed_url): super(GnocchiPublisher, self).__init__(conf, parsed_url) # TODO(jd) allow to override Gnocchi endpoint via the host in the URL options = urlparse.parse_qs(parsed_url.query) self.filter_project = options.get('filter_project', ["gnocchi"])[-1] resources_definition_file = options.get('resources_definition_file', ["gnocchi_resources.yaml"])[-1] archive_policy = options.get('archive_policy', [None])[-1] self.resources_definition = self._load_resources_definitions( conf, archive_policy, resources_definition_file) timeout = options.get('timeout', [6.05])[-1] oslo_cache.configure(conf) if conf.cache.enabled: conf, cache_region) self._gnocchi = gnocchi_client.get_gnocchiclient( conf, request_timeout=timeout) def _load_resources_definitions(self, conf, archive_policy, resources_definition_file): conf, {}, resources_definition_file, archive_policy, plugin_manager)) name=self.filter_project) self.filter_project = None return (self.filter_project and self.gnocchi_project_id and ( def publish_samples(self, data): def publish_events(self, events):
deleted_lines: from ceilometer import dispatcherclass GnocchiDispatcher(dispatcher.MeterDispatcherBase, dispatcher.EventDispatcherBase): """Dispatcher class for recording metering data into the Gnocchi service. The dispatcher class records each meter into the gnocchi service configured in ceilometer configuration file. An example configuration may [dispatcher_gnocchi] archive_policy = low To enable this dispatcher, the following section needs to be present in ceilometer.conf file [DEFAULT] meter_dispatchers = gnocchi event_dispatchers = gnocchi def __init__(self, conf): super(GnocchiDispatcher, self).__init__(conf) self.conf = conf self.filter_service_activity = ( conf.dispatcher_gnocchi.filter_service_activity) self.resources_definition = self._load_resources_definitions(conf) oslo_cache.configure(self.conf) if self.conf.cache.enabled: self.conf, cache_region) self._gnocchi = gnocchi_client.get_gnocchiclient(conf) @classmethod def _load_resources_definitions(cls, conf): conf, {}, conf.dispatcher_gnocchi.resources_definition_file, conf.dispatcher_gnocchi.archive_policy, plugin_manager)) name=self.conf.dispatcher_gnocchi.filter_project) self.filter_service_activity = False return (self.filter_service_activity and self.gnocchi_project_id and ( def record_metering_data(self, data): # We may have receive only one counter on the wire if not isinstance(data, list): data = [data] def record_events(self, events):

it uses stestr only

commit_message:
Add all services to container scenarios

This commit brings the multinode containers scenario files closer to
their BM variants to add missing services and turning pacemaker on.
These require refactorings in OOOQ in order to support non-containerized
to containerized upgrade jobs across releases. Ceph-ansible is also
going to be switched separately.

Co-Authored-By: Jiri Stransky <jistr@redhat.com>
Depends-On: Ie0e8de54794a9259c0aeb8c67ae0f6a908844093
Change-Id: Icb659509b38575534be27a1881dbe671c40a5436
Related-Bug: #1714905
Related-Bug: #1712070

Once we are able to deploy and # upgrade pacemakerized and containerized overcloud, we should remove # this file and use normal CI multinode environments/scenarios. # NOTE: This is needed because of upgrades from Ocata to Pike. We # deploy the initial environment with Ocata templates, and # overcloud-resource-registry.yaml there doesn't have this Docker # mapping at all. After we stop CI'ing Ocata->Pike upgrade, we can # remove this. OS::TripleO::Services::Docker: OS::Heat::None OS::TripleO::Services::NovaMigrationTarget: OS::Heat::None

subject: dpkg: fake initctl version now parseable by puppet
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-27 19:14:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/249d2b341ef1e346fa7c852b939013e9c75b8b2e', 'message': "dpkg: fake initctl version now parseable by puppet

To prevent daemon from starting, the dpkg element override /sbin/initctl
with a custom dummy script.  Puppet invokes at it with '--version' to
extract the version from the first line but that is left un matched and
cause an exception in Puppet.

Puppet match the first line using:

  /inictl \(upstart (.*)\//

The 'tripleo' causes it to fail.  Instead grab the original version
string to please Puppet.

For the context: on Ubuntu Trusty, I am building an image with Puppet
which provision a service that should not start on boot:

 service { 'foo':
   ensure  => 'stopped',
   enabled => false,  # Disabled it on boot/upstart
 }

The Puppet upstart providers first 'initctl --version' and raise an
exception since no match is returned.

Change-Id: I0770b5ba0056cf12eca830b6a80585659c16f335

commit_message:
dpkg: fake initctl version now parseable by puppet

To prevent daemon from starting, the dpkg element override /sbin/initctl
with a custom dummy script.  Puppet invokes at it with '--version' to
extract the version from the first line but that is left un matched and
cause an exception in Puppet.

Puppet match the first line using:

  /initctl \(upstart ([^\)]*)\)/)

The 'tripleo' part of the string causes the match to fail.  Instead
change it to 'upstart' to please Puppet.

For the context: on Ubuntu Trusty, I am building an image with Puppet
which provision a service that should not start on boot:

 service { 'foo':
   ensure  => 'stopped',
   enabled => false,  # Disabled it on boot/upstart
 }

The Puppet upstart providers first 'initctl --version' and raise an
exception since no match is returned.

Change-Id: I0770b5ba0056cf12eca830b6a80585659c16f335
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/05/322305/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: initctl_ver=$($TARGET_ROOT/sbin/initctl --version)echo "${upstart_ver}" unset initctl_ver

This patch adds missing 'autospec' to unit tests in /tests/unit/dhcp/.

Change-Id: I476807487a4cf98ddb5f27907f9aeeeab68d02bf

commit_message:
Add missing 'autospec' to unit tests - /unit/dhcp/

Proposing adding [H210] hacking check in tox.ini to require ‘autospec’,
‘spec’, or ‘spec_set’ in mock.patch/mock.patch.object calls.

This patch adds missing 'autospec' to unit tests in /tests/unit/dhcp/.

By using autospec=True, assert errors can be caught. [H210] requires that some
value for autospec, spec, or spec_set is defined. It could be autospec=False.

More patches to follow to cover all the unit tests to enable [H210] in
tox.ini.

Change-Id: I476807487a4cf98ddb5f27907f9aeeeab68d02bf

DNM: Test python_provide macro with python-keystoneclient

This is a test of the python_provide macro, to see how it works and
check if it passes all CIs.

subject: Add python_provide macro for SUSE
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rpm-packaging refs/changes/71/465971/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # python_provide macro, imported from the Fedora python-rpm-macros package # http://pkgs.fedoraproject.org/cgit/rpms/python-rpm-macros.git/ %python_provide() %{lua: function string.starts(String,Start) return string.sub(String,1,string.len(Start))==Start end package = rpm.expand("%{?1}") vr = rpm.expand("%{?epoch:%{epoch}:}%{version}-%{release}") if (string.starts(package, "python2-")) then if (rpm.expand("%{?buildarch}") ~= "noarch") then str = "Provides: python-" .. string.sub(package,9,string.len(package)) .. "%{?_isa} = " .. vr print(rpm.expand(str)) end print("\\nProvides: python-") print(string.sub(package,9,string.len(package))) print(" = ") print(vr) --Obsoleting the previous default python package print("\\nObsoletes: python-") print(string.sub(package,9,string.len(package))) print(" < ") print(vr) elseif (string.starts(package, "python" .. rpm.expand("%{python3_pkgversion}") .. "-")) then --No unversioned provides as python3 is not default elseif (rpm.expand("%{?python3_other_pkgversion}") ~= "" and string.starts(package, "python" .. rpm.expand("%{python3_other_pkgversion}") .. "-")) then --No unversioned provides as python3_other is not default elseif (string.starts(package, "pypy-")) then --No unversioned provides as pypy is not default elseif (string.starts(package, "pypy3-")) then --No unversioned provides as pypy is not default elseif (string.starts(package, "python-")) then --Providing the current default python print("Provides: python2-") print(string.sub(package,8,string.len(package))) print(" = ") print(vr) else print("%python_provide: ERROR: ") print(package) print(" not recognized.") end }

commit_message:
Optimize mistral queries for 'get_task_executions'

During workflow executions there are a lot of calls of function
'find_task_executions_by_name' from lookup_utils. This function
internally calls 'get_task_executions' with two filters: name and
workflow_execution_id.

To optimize this call it's reasonable to add a composite db index
by these two fields.

Another optimization is to explicitely disable sorting by 'created_at',
because it's unnecessary in this particulat case.

Change-Id: Ife150a384575cc4ad2fe45dc093816b48268df6f

commit_message:
Add yaml and json parsing functions

Sometimes you'll get a string back from some action (like swift
get_object) and it will be in either a yaml or json format. These
functions will allow you to parse those into a useful object.

Change-Id: I375219f4b019319e1b3d756dca512f7f90cd097f

commit_message:
bagpipe-bgp: avoid duplicate Route Targets

If a route target is passed multiple times in import_targets or
multiple times in export_targets, this results in various kinds
of benign errors, and for export the weird behavior of advertising
a route with a given RT present more than once.

Removing duplicates avoid these weirdnesses.

Change-Id: Ibeeae7e90096befc0b92e89ca88b772f2b208f55

commit_message:
Validate library files for documentation string

The ansible library files should all have a DOCUMENTATION and EXAMPLES variables.
This commit makes the CI fail in case the variables are missing from the
files in 'validations/library' subdirectory.

Change-Id: Ibd38d893ed1ff0e1032c2f97c0eb1e71d3897ea4

subject: Add a note about relogging in as the stack user when docker commands fail
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-10-12 14:25:15.000000000', 'files': ['doc/source/install/installation/installing.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-docs/commit/e3b006853dbbe957eae9da2ce00ae66a4507e2c6', 'message': "Add a note about relogging in as the stack user when docker commands fail

We currently do the following to add the 'stack' user on the undercloud
to the 'docker' group so it can access the docker daemon (when the local
docker registry option is enabled):
...
if str2bool(hiera('enable_docker_registry', true)) {
  group { 'docker':
    ensure => 'present',
  }
  user { 'docker_user':
    name => hiera('tripleo_install_user'),
    groups => 'docker',
    notify => Service['docker'],
  }
  include ::tripleo::profile::base::docker_registry
}
...

For this to work the stack user needs to logoff and logon again.
Closes-Bug: #1722498

Change-Id: Ia1f76f61828c119667879c41f1ad5d86b8901adb
"}]
commit_message:
Add a note about relogging in as the stack user when docker commands fail

We currently do the following to add the 'stack' user on the undercloud
to the 'docker' group so it can access the docker daemon (when the local
docker registry option is enabled):
...
if str2bool(hiera('enable_docker_registry', true)) {
  group { 'docker':
    ensure => 'present',
  }
  user { 'docker_user':
    name => hiera('tripleo_install_user'),
    groups => 'docker',
    notify => Service['docker'],
  }
  include ::tripleo::profile::base::docker_registry
}
...

For this to work the stack user needs to logoff and logon again.
Closes-Bug: #1722498

Change-Id: Ia1f76f61828c119667879c41f1ad5d86b8901adb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-docs refs/changes/90/511490/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. note:: If running ``docker`` commands as a stack user after an undercloud install fail with a permission error, log out and log in again. The stack user does get added to the docker group during install, but that change gets reflected only after a new login.
